prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup optimized to observe the 12CO 1-0 transition (spw2).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- SENSITIVITY: We consider that the bulk of CO 1-0 emission detected with SEST (188mJy) will mainly emerge from three regions (head, heart and body of the Bird), each of 2x2 arcsec in size. At a resolution of 1", the total flux will then be distributed in 12 ALMA beams. We aim at obtaining a S/N~10 of a 16mJy/beam signal for a 20 km/s spectral resolution (same as that obtained with SEST), thus resulting in an rms~1.6mJy/beam. We have simulated the ALMA observations (not shown in the proposal) using slices of our PaB VLT/SINFONI map, and we recover an rms similar to the one needed to obtain 10sigma detections for the observing time (~5min on source) calculated in the OT.
- IMAGING REQUIREMENTS: The maximum recoverable scale is ~8arcsec, i.e., much larger than the expected size of emission per velocity channel (~ 2x2 arcsec regions whose velocity gradients are within 10 km/s, see Fig. 3b). The Bird components fit within the inner region of the ALMA primary beam (see Figs. 2 and 3 in the proposal), so the observations can be done with a single pointing without ACA. The requested angular resolution allows the reconstruction of the distinct Bird components.
- CORRELATOR SETUP We request the use of four basebands with the largest bandwidth offered for spectral line (1875 MHz). This will allow to detect the three CO features close to the systemic velocity (cz=14576 km/s), each with an approximate width of 150 km/s, plus additional red- or blue-shifted components, if any. The three remaining basebands will be use for continuum and to search for other transitions, for example, transition 13C18O in the spw1. To reliably resolve the spectral lines of each component, we request a spectral resolution of 20km/s (comparable to that obtained with SEST) throughout the band, which if needed, can be further averaged to improve the S/N.
We note that the correlator can provide a spectral resolution ~23 km/s when averaging by a factor of 16. As the OT gives basically the same integration time when averaging by 8 or by 16, we choose to average by 8, thus obtaining a spectral resolution ~10km/s, which can be averaged once more when reducing the data if a higher S/N is needed.
- CALIBRATION no special requirements
- BANDPASS ACCURACY We consider a small overlap of the basebands to account for the roll-off at their edges, thus avoiding the consequent loss of sensitivity.
- SCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS none

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(3-2) and dust
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup optimized to observe the 3-2 transition from 13CO (spw0), 12CO (spw3), and dust emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- SENSITIVITY: The sensitivity in this science goal is motivated by the detection of the 13CO 3-2 spectral line (expected to be 20 times weaker than that of 12CO 3-2).
We consider that the bulk of CO 3-2 emission detected with APEX (610mJy) will mainly emerge from three regions (head, heart and body of the Bird), each of 2x2 arcsec in size. At a resolution of 1", the total flux will then be distributed in 12 ALMA beams, resulting in a peak of ~50mJy/beam. We consider a 12CO/13CO ratio of 20. Then, in order to detect a 2.5mJy/beam signal with S/N~3, we request an rms~0.85mJy/beam per 20 km/s width channel (as in science goal 1). This rms will also result in a very high S/N ratio for the detection of dust emission expected to be ~70mJy in band 7.
The choice of representative window in this science goal will have a huge impact on the total observing time, owing to the strong water absorption at nu_rest ~ 341GHz. To secure our detection of both 12 and 13 CO, we use as representative window that one with the highest central frequency.
- IMAGING REQUIREMENTS: As CO 3-2 will trace denser (and thus more compact) gas than CO 1-0, we expect that the maximum recoverable size will be similar to the expected size of emission per velocity channel (~ 2x2 arcsec regions whose velocity gradients are within 10km/s, see Fig. 3b). The Bird components fit within a ~5x8arcsec region (see Figs. 2 and 3 in the proposal), so the observations can be done with a single pointing at band 7. The requested angular resolution allows the reconstruction of the distinct Bird components.
- CORRELATOR SETUP we request the use of four basebands with the largest bandwidth offered for spectral line (1875 MHz). This will allow us to detect the three CO features close to the systemic velocity (cz=14576 km/s), each with an approximate width of 150 km/s, plus additional red- or blue-shifted components, if any. The remaining basebands will be used for continuum and to search for other transitions if any. To reliably resolve the spectral lines of each component, we request a spectral resolution of 20km/s (comparable to that obtained with SEST) throughout the band, which provides us with some margin to improve the S/N.
The correlator allows a maximum spectral averaging by a factor of 16; this results in a spectral resolution ~7km/s, which can be averaged once more when reducing the data if a higher S/N is needed, thus reaching a spectral resolution ~20km/s, as we specified above.
- CALIBRATION no special requirements
- BANDPASS ACCURACY We consider a small overlap of the basebands to account for the roll-off at their edges, thus avoiding the consequent loss of sensitivity.
- SCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS none

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(6-5) and dust
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup optimized to observe the 12CO 6-5 transition and dust emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- SENSITIVITY: Given the expectation for highly-excited high-J CO transitions, we consider that the CO 6-5 line is at least twice as bright as the CO 3-2 line, i.e., ~1220mJy/beam.
As done in the previous science goal, we consider that the CO 6-5 emission will mainly emerge from three regions (head, heart and body of the Bird), each of 2x2 arcsec in size, similar to the maximum recoverable size. At a resolution of 0.6" (the lowest resolution that can be obtained with the 12m array in band 9), the total flux will then be distributed in ~33 ALMA beams (considering the three Bird components), resulting in a peak of ~37mJy/beam. To detect the 6-5 spectral line with S/N~5, we request an rms~7.4mJy/beam per 20 km/s width channel (as in science goals 1 and 2). This rms will also result in a very high S/N ratio for the detection of dust emission expected to be ~680mJy in this band.
- IMAGING REQUIREMENTS: CO 6-5 will trace denser (and thus more compact) gas than CO 1-0, and thus, as in the case of CO3-2, we expect that the maximum recoverable size will be similar to the expected size of emission per velocity channel (~ 2x2" regions whose velocity gradients are within 10 km/s, see Fig. 3b). The Bird components fit within a ~5x8arcsec region (see Figs. 2 and 3 in the proposal), so the observations can be done with three pointings at band 9.
The requested angular resolution (0.6 arcsec) allows the reconstruction of the distinct Bird components, and when convolved with a larger beam size (~1 arcsec) it will allow a more direct comparison with the CO 1-0 and 3-2 emission.
- CORRELATOR SETUP We request the use of four basebands with the largest bandwidth offered for spectral line (1875 MHz). This will allow us to detect the three CO features close to the systemic velocity (cz=14576 km/s), each with an approximate width of 150 km/s, plus additional red- or blue-shifted components, if any. The remaining basebands will be use for continuum and to search for other transitions if any. To reliably resolve the spectral lines of each component, we request a spectral resolution of 20km/s (comparable to that obtained with SEST) throughout the band, and to have a margin to improve the S/N.
The correlator allows a maximum spectral averaging by a factor of 16; this results in a spectral resolution ~3.5km/s, which can be averaged once more when reducing the data if a higher S/N is needed, thus reaching a spectral resolution ~20km/s, as we specified above.
- CALIBRATION no special requirements
- BANDPASS ACCURACY The basebands in this science goal have been tuned to avoid as much as possible water absorption features
- SCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS none

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Bird is a luminous infrared galaxy (LIRG), logL_IR(L_sun)=11.89, product of a triple merger. The ongoing star formation (SF) in the least massive of the components (the head) outshines that of the primary nuclei (the heart and the body) as evidenced by our Spitzer-24um imaging, hence dominating the LIRG phenomenon in the Bird. This clashes with the commonly accepted major merger scenario in which the SF is expected to be higher in central compact regions. The Bird has a global high SF rate of ~190Msun/yr and shows spectroscopic evidence for outflowing gas reaching v~600 km/s. The complexity of this system makes it a perfect laboratory to study star-forming regions with a wide range of physical conditions, which we can probe with the aid of sub-mm observations. For doing this, we propose to perform a detailed study of the gas (12CO 1-0, 3-2 and 6-5, 13CO 3-2) and dust continuum of the three NIR-bright components of the Bird. The proposed ALMA observations, together with our NIR, MIR and optical data, represent a unique dataset that will allow us to test the major merger scenario, whilst making the Bird a local template to be compared to IR luminous high-z galaxy mergers.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This project is based on the Cycle 1 proposal with Code: 2012.1.00157.S Title: ALMA observations of IRAS 19115-2124: A glimpse of the Bird's anatomy PI name: C. Romero-Canizales
